title: North Andover officer shot by colleague back in jail just days after release
author: Ross Cristantiello
bullets: Kelsey Fitzsimmons, a North Andover police officer, was ordered back to jail for failing to comply with alcohol testing.
Fitzsimmons, shot by a fellow officer, was unable to use a breathalyzer due to severe injuries from the incident.
Her attorneys suggest alternative urine testing, citing her health and safety concerns in Correctional Center as reasons for release.

title: The owners of the orange dinosaur are suing Saugus. Here’s why.
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: TB Holdings LLC is suing Saugus in federal court over alleged project delays and a $200,000 payment demand.
Developers allege Town Manager Scott Crabtree demanded payment to the parks department to progress Essex Landing developments.
TB Holdings seeks damages and claims constitutional violations due to slowed development and unresponsive public records requests.

title: Heidi Watney happily returns to Fenway with Apple TV+ for Yankees-Red Sox: ‘It’s like coming home’
author: Chad Finn
bullets: Heidi Watney returns to Fenway Park with Apple TV+ for the Red Sox vs. Yankees series.
Watney was a NESN Red Sox reporter from 2008 to 2011, now with Apple TV+'s Friday Night Baseball.
She values her Boston roots, recalling fond memories with Don Orsillo and Jerry Remy at NESN.

title: Brian Walshe reportedly stabbed in jail while awaiting murder trial
author: Abby Patkin
bullets: Brian Walshe was stabbed at Norfolk County Jail while awaiting trial for allegedly murdering his wife in 2023.
He was treated for non-life-threatening injuries at Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center and returned to the jail.
The incident, involving a makeshift weapon, is under investigation; Walshe's trial is scheduled for next month.

title: Former Patriots players share drastic measures Bill Belichick would take for team’s trips to Miami
author: Conor Roche
bullets: Bill Belichick frequently changed the Patriots' travel plans to Miami, experimenting with different hotels to improve performance.
The Patriots have struggled in Miami, losing their last five games there with only rare wins in previous seasons.
Ex-players Brian Hoyer and David Andrews discussed the challenges of playing in Miami despite diverse strategies by Belichick.

title: Amid former Celtic Terry Rozier’s gambling investigation, Hornets cancel ‘Sports Betting’ theme night
author: Aidan Buchanan
bullets: Miami Heat's Terry Rozier is under investigation for irregular betting patterns during his time with the Hornets.
The Charlotte Hornets canceled their 'Sports Betting Night' after announcing it would coincide with Rozier's return.
In a previous game, bets totaling nearly $14,000 were placed on Rozier, leading to a sports betting scandal probe.

title: Former Boston Children’s Hospital doctor pleads guilty to child porn charges
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: Christopher Sheerer, 37, a former Boston Children's Hospital fellow, pleaded guilty to federal child pornography charges.
Sheerer admitted to distribution and possession of child pornography and sexual exploitation of children.
Authorities found multiple sexual abuse images and videos on Sheerer's devices during a search of his Boston residence.

title: Wu responds to Kraft’s decision to drop out of mayoral race
author: Ross Cristantiello
bullets: Mayor Michelle Wu expressed gratitude for Josh Kraft's city dedication after he exited the mayoral race.
Kraft decided to donate $3 million to local charities instead of continuing his campaign against Wu.
Kraft's withdrawal leaves uncertainty about ballot changes before the November 4 general election.

title: Travis Barker and Kourtney Kardashian toured Salem
author: Megan Johnson
bullets: Travis Barker and Kourtney Kardashian visited Salem after Blink-182's concert in Gilford, NH, on Tuesday.
The couple joined a Witch City Walking Tour, exploring local sites like Old Town Hall and the Bewitched Sculpture.
They dined at Gulu-Gulu Cafe in Salem with their son, Rocky, and remained largely unnoticed by other patrons.

title: Suspect in Charlie Kirk killing had become ‘more political’ and likely acted alone, authorities say
author: The Associated Press
bullets: Tyler Robinson, 22, arrested for the shooting of Charlie Kirk, signaled responsibility to a family friend, per Utah Gov. Spencer Cox.
Robinson opposed Kirk's viewpoints, acted alone, and left engravings on bullets; investigation by state and FBI continues.
Charlie Kirk was shot during an event at Utah Valley University; his death prompts bipartisan condemnation of political violence.
